presentation.title: Water supply, wet year annual precipitation
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from water regulation and supply by ecosystems under wet year annual precipitation levels
presentation.description: Values resulting from the provision of surface and groundwater water supply by ecosystems, including precipitation, ecosystems capable of providing groundwater recharge or delivery of surface water through streams, lakes, or reservoirs.

page.name: Surface water supply assessment
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This model considers surface water supply for various human beneficiary groups, including agriculture, industry, domestic use, and in-stream flow to support hydroelectric power generation, navigation, or recreation. The model uses wet year annual precipitation as the primary source of surface water to estimate upper-bound values for water supply in a wet year. These models collectively map flows sources of surface water (precipitation, snowmelt, springs, baseflow to rivers, incoming water transfers), sinks (areas of groundwater infiltration or evapotranspiration), and beneficiary groups and link these via a flow model accounting for the downstream movement of floodwater.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Annual precipitation, wet year
page.title: Annual precipitation, wet year
page.description:
Annual precipitation, wet year.

Role in models

Precipitation data are used as the most important "source" of surface and groundwater. Particularly in arid and semiarid regions, where year-to-year rainfall is highly variable, it is more realistic for us to model the range of variability in water supply, based on a representative wet and dry year, than to model mean annual precipitation. Precipitation runs off into water bodies where it is used or recharges groundwater through percolation to aquifers. Data are currently at an annual time scale; finer temporal resolution could be added to the ARIES system in the future to better account for seasonal wet and dry seasons and their impacts on water supply. These data are passed to the flow model to estimate actual water supply used given the locations of beneficiaries, their demand, and infiltration or evapotranspiration that occur as water flows across the landscape.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of precipitation per year.

Source

PRISM Climate Group (U.S. data).
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: PRISM
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual groundwater recharge
page.title: Annual groundwater recharge
page.description:
Annual groundwater recharge, wet year.

Role in models

Groundwater recharge data are the "source" of groundwater. Groundwater then moves through aquifers based on various geologic factors, or is extracted by wells for use. These data are passed to the flow model to estimate actual groundwater used given the locations of beneficiaries and their demand, along with any springs or baseflow to rivers that naturally converts groundwater back to surface water.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of groundwater recharge per year.

Source

U.S. Geological Survey.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: U.S. Geological Survey.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Slope
page.title: Slope
page.description:
Slope strongly affects runoff by influencing potential infiltration.

Role in models

Since hydrologic soils group classifications do not account for slope, we use slope data along with HSG and impervious surface data to estimate the soil infiltration component in the surface water sink models. Greater infiltration is expected on level slopes than on steep slopes where runoff occurs quickly.

Representation

The data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Data are derived from a global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Derived from Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Hydrologic soils group
page.title: Hydrologic soils group
page.description:
Different soil types have different infiltration capacities. See http://www.ems-i.com/wmshelp/Hydrologic_Models/Calculators/Composite_Runoff_Coefficients/Selecting_the_Method.htm.

Role in models

Soils are classified from group A (highest infiltraiton capacity) to D (lowest infiltration capacity); group accounts for maximum yearly wetness, degree of soil freezing, bare soil surface, and swelling of clays, but does not account for slope. We use HSG along with slope and impervious surface data to estimate the soil infiltration component of surface water sink models.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

University of Vermont Spatial Analysis Lab, derived from FAO soils data.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Percent impervious cover
page.title: Percent impervious cover
page.description:
The amount of impervious surface (buildings, roads, parking lots, etc.) on the landscape.

Role in models

We use impervious surface along with slope and hydrologic soils group to estimate the soil infiltration component of the surface water sink models. Zero infiltration is expected on impervious surfaces.

Representation

Data represent the percentage of the land surface under impervious cover.

Source

NOAA-NGDC global impervious surface data.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Data source: Data source: NOAA-NGDC global impervious surface data/br> Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Mountain front recharge zones
page.title: Mountain front recharge zones
page.description:
The intersection of valley fill alluvium and mountain fronts.

Role in models

In the southwestern United States, mountain fronts and stream channels are two primary areas of groundwater. recharge. They are thus used as the inputs to a probabilistic model of infiltration.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of potential mountainfront recharge zones, represented as a 1,600-meter wide band around the base of mountainfronts where subsurface geology shifts to valley fill alluvium. Areas of limestone bedrock, which promote high levels of infiltration, are also included in this layer.

Source

Derived from Arizona Geographic Information Council geology data.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Geographic Information Council.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Stream channels
page.title: Stream channels
page.description:
Perennial, intermittent, and ephemeral stream channels.

Role in models

In the southwestern United States, mountain fronts and stream channels are two primary areas of groundwater. recharge. They are thus used as the inputs to a probabilistic model of infiltration.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of perennial, intermittent, or ephemeral stream channels.

Source

Arizona Geographic Information Council.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Geographic Information Council.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil infiltration
page.title: Soil infiltration
page.description:
The total surface water absorbed by the soil, potentially becoming available as groundwater.

Role in models

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of soil and geologic characteristics on infiltration. Results are summed with evapotranspiration to give total surface water sink values, and then passed to the flow model to estimate actual surface water availability given the location of sources of surface water and users of water. In the absence of direct data on infiltration, the results of this model can also be used as source data for groundwater flow models.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of water infiltrated per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of water infiltrated. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Annual maximum temperature
page.title: Annual maximum temperature
page.description:
Annual maximum temperature influences water demand by plants and potential levels of evaporation.

Role in models

Particularly in water limited environments, annual maximum temperature is used as an influence on evapotranspiration, with greater evapotranspiration under higher temperatures.

Representation

The data are in physical units of degrees celsius.

Source

PRISM Climate Group (U.S. data); WorldClim (global data).
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: WorldClim, PRISM
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types will promote or reduce infiltration and evapotranspiration.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as an input to a probabilistic model for evapotranspiration, which is part of the sink model for surface water.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from land cover classes.

Source

2001 National Land Cover Dataset (U.S. data); Veracruz land cover dataset (La Antigua case study).
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Percent tree canopy cover
page.title: Percent tree canopy cover
page.description:
Percent tree canopy cover. Tree canopy cover influences rooting depths, root densities, and transpiration rates.

Role in models

Tree canopy cover is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation toward evapotranpiration. All else being equal, we expect greater evapotranspiration under higher tree canopy cover.

Representation

Data represent the percentage of the land surface under tree canopy cover.

Source

)NLCD 2001 data (U.S. data); GLCF (University of Maryland, global data).
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset, University of Maryland Global Land Cover Facility.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Evapotranspiration class
page.title: Evapotranspiration class
page.description:
The total surface water evaporated or taken up by vegetation and transpired, becoming no longer available as surface or groundwater.

Role in models

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of vegetation and climatic characteristics on evapotranspiration. Results are summed with infiltration to give total surface water sink values, and then passed to the flow model to estimate actual surface water availability given the location of sources of surface water and users of water.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of water evaporated or transpired per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of water infiltrated. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Surface water sink
page.title: Surface water sink
page.description:
The sum of infiltration and evapotranspiration, e.g., all surface water that returns to the atmosphere or infiltrates to groundwater, becoming unavailable as downstream surface water.

Role in models

The surface water sink is the total water that was once surface water but is no longer available as surface water. These data are passed to the surface water flow model, which calculates actual surface water availability for beneficiaries, given precipitation levels, the activity of sinks, and use of and demand for water.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of water infiltrated, evaporated, or transpired per year.

Source

Calculated as the sum of outputs from a probabilistic models for infiltration and evapotranspiration.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Industrial surface water use
page.title: Industrial surface water use
page.description:
Water use by industrial water users.

Role in models

Results are summed with other types of water users to give total water demand. Total demand is passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Instituto de Ecologia, INECOL.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Agricultural surface water use
page.title: Agricultural surface water use
page.description:
Water use by agricultural water users.

Role in models

Results are summed with other types of water users to give total water demand. Total demand is passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Instituto de Ecologia, INECOL.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Residential surface water use
page.title: Residential surface water use
page.description:
Water use by residential water users.

Role in models

Results are summed with other types of water users to give total water demand. Total demand is passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Instituto de Ecologia, INECOL.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Aquacultural surface water use
page.title: Aquacultural surface water use
page.description:
Water use by aquacultural water users.

Role in models

Results are summed with other types of water users to give total water demand. Total demand is passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Instituto de Ecologia, INECOL.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Total surface water use
page.title: Total surface water use
page.description:
The sum of water use by residential, industrial, agricultural, and aquacultural water users.

Role in models

Results are the final water use values. These are passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Calculated deterministically as the sum of residential, industrial, agricultural, and aquacultural water use.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Surface diversion capacity
page.title: Surface diversion capacity
page.description:
Surface diversions, primarily for agriculture, are a key surface water user, and are the only surface water user for our San Pedro case study.

Role in models

Results are the final surface water use values for the San Pedro. These are passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of water diversion capacity per year.

Source

Digitized the locations and level of diversion capacity for surface diversions in the San Pedro watershed.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Well pumping capacity
page.title: Well pumping capacity
page.description:
Groundwater wells locations and use data where available, are the source of use data for groundwater flow models.

Role in models

Results are the final groundwater use values for the San Pedro. These could be passed to a groundwater flow model to estimate actual groundwater availability given the location of infiltration zone locations and groundwater recharge quantities and demand for water.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of water pumping capacity per year.

Source

Arizona Department of Water Resources (U.S.); INECOL (Mexico).
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Department of Water Resources Wells-55 Database.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Elevation
page.title: Elevation
page.description:
Elevation above sea level.

Role in models

A digital elevation model is used along with hydrography data to route water across the land surface. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which water then follows through the stream network.

Representation

The data are in physical units of meters above sea level.

Source

Global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Rivers
page.title: Rivers
page.description:
River and stream locations.

Role in models

River and stream locations, or hydrography data, are used to route surface water. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which water then follows through the stream network.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of rivers and streams.

Source

Arizona Geographic Information Council; Veracruz hydrgraphy data.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Geographic Information Council.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Possible surface water flow
page.title: Possible surface water flow
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* represent the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the movement of surface water via topography and stream networks, when not accounting for sinks (infiltration or evapotranspirative losses of surface water).
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Possible surface water supply
page.title: Possible surface water supply
page.description:
Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity actually has the ability to reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape. Flow analysis allows us to identify which particular portion of the total source quantity is actually generating carriers that reach the users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account the result of use values, the structure of the landscape and the flow paths of the carrier, producing this *possible source map*. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the portion of the source field that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map shows surface water in its initial source location, that is capable of providing water to human beneficiaries when accounting for flow paths but not accounting for sinks (i.e., potentially can provide water to human beneficiaries).
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Possible surface water use
page.title: Possible surface water use
page.description:
*Possible use maps* show the locations of users on the landscape that can receive a benefit due to flow connections with a source of an ecosystem service carrier, but may or may not actually receive the carrier due to the action of sinks. For provisioning services, potential use identifies areas where it is physically possible for a benefit to be received. For preventive services, potential use identifies areas that may be damaged by a detrimental carrier if sinks do not prevent such damage.
This map represents water actually reaching a user, but not accounting for the activity of sinks.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual surface water flow
page.title: Actual surface water flow
page.description:
The *actual flow density* map shows the flow paths that deliver actual services to humans. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
In this case, the density of actual flows represents the movement of surface water when accounting for flow paths and sinks (i.e., transitions from surface to groundwater, or evapotranspirative losses of surface water).
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Used surface water supply
page.title: Used surface water supply
page.description:
The *actual source map* shows the portion of the source map that is relevant to the provision of a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics. For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier were neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows sources of surface water transitions that are capable of providing water to human beneficiaries when accounting for surface flow paths and sinks (i.e., areas that actually provide water to human beneficiaries).
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual surface water sink
page.title: Actual surface water sink
page.description:
The *actual sink map* shows the portion of the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns. For provisioning services, such sinks are responsible for reducing the benefits compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows the locations where surface water transitions into groundwater (via infiltration) or atmospheric water (via evapotranspiration), becoming unavailable for use as surface water.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Satisfied surface water demand
page.title: Satisfied surface water demand
page.description:
The *actual use map* shows the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users located across the landscape.
This map shows the portion of demand for water satisfied by the actual supply of surface water.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Unusable surface water supply
page.title: Unusable surface water supply
page.description:
The *inaccessible source map* shows those areas of the source map whose values are irrelevant to the delivery of the service, because of the impossibility of reaching users given the relevant ecosystem services flow path. For provisioning services, this is the portion of the value that must be subtracted from the total source map to define a maximum potential benefit for the users. For preventive services, it shows those areas that have no potential of producing damage because the flow dynamics prevent the carrier from reaching any significant user.
This map shows the source locations of surface water that are not available to human users because their flow paths do not move them in a direction where they can be accessed by human beneficiaries.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Inaccessible surface water demand
page.title: Inaccessible surface water demand
page.description:
The *inaccessible use map* shows those areas of the use map where beneficiaries fail to receive a service because of the impossibility of reaching users given the relevant ecosystem services flow path.
This map shows areas of demand for surface water that goes unsatisfied due to a lack of surface or groundwater flow connections between sources of water and the location of water users.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Sunk surface water flow
page.title: Sunk surface water flow
page.description:
The *blocked flow map* shows the flow paths that could have delivered the service carrier to humans based on the flow routes and the source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss in possible flow of beneficial services to the users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows water flows that fail to reach a user because it encountered a sink and transitions from surface water into the atmospheric or groundwater.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Sunk surface water supply
page.title: Sunk surface water supply
page.description:
The *blocked source map* shows the part of the source map that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of the users and the flow dynamics, but was blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it reaches the users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but was blocked by natural features.
This map shows the source locations of surface water that fails to reach a user due to their encountering a sink and transitioning from surface water into the atmosphere or groundwater.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Blocked surface water demand
page.title: Blocked surface water demand
page.description:
The *blocked use map* shows those users that would have been reached by the service carrier based only on the source and the flow dynamics, but were not reached because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that has not been accrued to users because of sinks; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users thanks to sink configuration.
For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and natural sink features.
This map shows demand for surface water that goes unsatisfied due to the action of sinks that transition water from surface water to inaccessible atmospheric moisture or groundwater.
page.see-also: The water supply section of the ARIES web site
